text: I think that the it's kind of reflex to
hold back AI in in the policy area
especially in criminal justice I think
is driven in large part by concerns
about fairness and I think that we do
that without thinking about the fairness
of the status quo so we've been doing we
have a paper that came out in the
quarterly Journal of economics last year
that I'll describe briefly for those of
you whose qjz subscriptions lapsed
somehow and so we got data from a large
anonymous American city of 8.6 million
people and in this city you can see that
fully ninety percent of the people who
judges are currently sending for
pretrial detention are African American
and Hispanic in a city where the general
population is not anything like ninety
percent African American or Hispanic
so in discrimination law they have this
concept of disparate impact where a
facially neutral neutral process
generates lured very disproportionate
harm against disadvantaged groups so we
showed that the judge is one of the
reasons that the judges are detaining
lots of people in general they're
deciding more people that they need to
because they're substantially miss
predicting defendant risk and if we
relied instead on the much more accurate
predictions of defendant risk from an
algorithm you could reduce the jail
population by 40 percent without any
increase in crime
that's the equivalent of being able to
close the jail at the end of July every
year without crime going up and what's
interesting about that is you know who
disproportionately benefits when we can
substantially improve a system that has
enormous disparate impact it is those
disadvantaged communities that we must
want to help and so in some sense you
know there's this underappreciated
potential benefit if we can get the
right rules and regulations in place to
realize it but there's this
underappreciated potential benefit of AI
to improve systems that are having
disparate impact right now
to create what you might think of is
like a disparate benefit
[Music]
